metadata.case_name: Purshottamdas Thakurdass and others v. Commissioner of Income Tax

facts.text: Assessee A (late Shri Purshottamdas Thakurdass) was a shareholder in Narandas Rajaram Ltd., which carried on business both in India and Pakistan, with profits accruing in both.
For assessment year 1949-50, portion of dividend attributable to profits accrued in Pakistan amounted to Rs. 2,722 for Assessee A.
On May 20, 1952, ITO included Rs. 2,722 in total income but held no income tax or super-tax payable.
ITO reopened assessment of 1949-50 due to order u/s 23A in respect of Industrial Corporation Ltd., deeming Rs. 579 to accrue to Assessee A.
In re-assessment order dated January 17, 1955, ITO brought to charge Rs. 579 (grossed) and Rs. 2,722 (Pakistan portion from Narandas Rajaram Ltd.).
Appellate Assistant Commissioner upheld assessment for both Rs. 579 and Rs. 2,722.
Appellate Tribunal upheld the order and referred first three questions to High Court, refused to refer supplementary question on withdrawal of relief u/s 23(3).
Bombay High Court by judgment dated March 17, 1958 answered three questions against Assessee and directed reference of supplementary question.
High Court by judgment dated April 14, 1960 answered supplementary question in favour of assessee.
High Court granted certificate on February 7, 1961 to Assessee A; CIT did not appeal against supplementary question judgment.

For assessment year 1952-53, net dividend from Narandas Rajaram Ltd. to Assessee A was Rs. 1,12,867, of which Rs. 23,167 attributable to Pakistan profits; ITO charged to tax, confirmed by AAC and Tribunal.
High Court granted certificate u/s 66A(2) on July 10, 1959 for 1952-53.

On October 14, 1952, Narandas Rajaram Ltd. resolved at general meeting to declare dividends: 4% on A Pref, 4% on B Pref, 32% on Ordinary free of tax, additional 13% on B Pref free of tax; one moiety payable on/after Oct 16, 1952, other moiety postponed within 2 months from remittances from Pakistan becoming free.
Company certificate u/s 20 stated half dividend payable on/after Oct 16, 1952, balance within 2 months after Pakistan remittances free.
For 1953-54, ITO included entire Rs. 1,71,992 dividend in Assessee A's total income; confirmed by AAC and Tribunal.
Tribunal referred three questions including Question D; High Court answered D in negative (against CIT), others against assessee; granted certificates to both.
Facts similar for other assessees, apart from amounts.
No certificate of assessment from other Dominion produced before ITO.

Company P&L debited Rs. 5,85,000 for total dividend; credits to Seventh Dividend Account Rs. 5,74,144-4-0, Income-tax Reserve Rs.10,500, Non-resident supertax Rs.355-12-0; later Seventh Dividend Account credit balance Rs.2,92,500 for unpaid moiety.

legal_issues.text: Whether the initiation of action under section 34 for the purpose of bringing to tax the net dividend income of Rs. 579 suitably grossed was valid?
Whether the said portion of the dividend income forms part of the assessee's total income as that term is defined in section 2(15) of the Indian Income Tax Act, 1922?
Whether having regard to the provisions of the Indo-Pakistan Agreement, the assessee is entitled to any relief on the said portion of dividend income?

Whether the other moiety of the dividend of Rs. 1,71,992 declared by the Company on 14-10-1952 is properly includible in the total income of the assessee of the previous year S.Y. 2008 for the assessment year 1953-54?

Whether on the facts and circumstances of the case, the relief allowed in the assessment under section 23(3) on that portion of dividend income from Narandas Rajaram Co. Private Ltd., which is attributable to the income of the Company arising in Pakistan can be withdrawn while making re-assessment under section 34(1)(b)?

petitioner_arguments.text: On true interpretation of Indo-Pakistan Agreement, each Dominion entitled to charge only proportion of income allotted to it under Agreement.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Indo-Pakistan Agreement, Article IV, Schedule item 8

petitioner_arguments.text: The resolution created only a contingent liability; dividend could not be said to have been paid in previous year for 1953-54.
Dividend not credited or distributed within meaning of s.16(2).

respondent_arguments.text: Each Dominion entitled to assess assessee on total income in normal way but allow abatement subject to conditions in Agreement.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Indo-Pakistan Agreement, Article IV, Article VI

respondent_arguments.text: Amount credited within meaning of s.16(2); P&L debited total dividend, credits to dividend account etc.

court_reasoning.text: First question academic as CIT did not appeal against High Court's judgment on supplementary question in favour of assessee.
Pakistan portion of dividend forms part of total income u/s 2(15); concession by counsel; High Court followed CIT v. Shanti K. Maheshwari.

Agreement Art. IV: each Dominion assesses in ordinary way under own laws, but allows abatement on excess over Schedule proportion; Schedule apportions for abatement calculation, not limiting assessment power; Art. VI supports as demand made without abatement initially if no certificate.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No certificate produced; assessee not entitled to relief.

court_reasoning.text: Dissent from Laxmidas not necessary; dividend not paid or credited u/s 16(2) as not unconditionally available to shareholder; no credit to assessee's separate account.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Follows J. Dalmia v. CIT: dividend paid/credited when unconditionally available.

holdings.text: Pakistan portion of dividend income forms part of total income u/s 2(15).
Assessee not entitled to relief under Indo-Pakistan Agreement as no certificate of assessment from other Dominion produced.
Other moiety of dividend Rs.1,71,992 not paid or credited u/s 16(2); not includible in total income for 1953-54.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income-Tax, Bombay City v. Shanti K. Maheshwari
precedents_cited.relevance: Pakistan dividend forms part of total income u/s 2(15)

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income Tax v. Laxmidas Mulraj Khatau
precedents_cited.relevance: High Court relied on for contingent liability; Supreme Court dissented per Dalmia

precedents_cited.case_name: J. Dalmia v. Commissioner of Income Tax, Delhi
precedents_cited.relevance: Dividend paid/credited u/s 16(2) when unconditionally available to shareholder

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income Tax Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: Definition of total income; deeming dividend paid/credited; reopening assessment; relief; reference to High Court; implementation of agreement

statutes_cited.name: Indo-Pakistan Agreement dated December 10, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Avoidance of double taxation; assessment in ordinary way with abatement on excess; proportion for dividends based on company profits

outcome.summary: All 12 appeals fail: assessee appeals on questions 1-3 dismissed (Q1 academic, Q2 conceded against assessee, Q3 no relief due to no certificate); CIT appeals on Q4 dismissed as moiety not paid/credited.

key_quotes.text: "Each Dominion shall make assessment in the ordinary way under its own laws and... shall allow an abatement equal to the lower amount of tax payable on such excess" - Art. IV.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Interprets Agreement as permitting full assessment with abatement only

key_quotes.text: "In general, dividend may be said to be paid... when the Company discharges its liability and makes the amount of dividend unconditionally available to the member" - Shah J. in Dalmia.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines when dividend deemed paid/credited u/s 16(2)
